review: If you're looking for a small, easy-to-use, elegant but extremely limited set top box and don't mind purchasing everything from iTunes, the Apple TV works. If you want something that's a portal to other content providers, you might want to consider something else.Make no mistake about it, Apple wants you to buy everything from them and nothing from anyone else. Nowhere is this strategy more evident than with the AppleTV. Other than Netflix and a couple of other services that, if not available, would render this product completely irrelevant, Apple makes sure you don't have access to competitors, like Flixster or Amazon. If you want a movie or television show and it's not on Netflix (and it probably won't be), you will have to purchase it, and the only place to get it is, you guessed it, iTunes. If you've purchased a digital copy of a movie on a cloud like Flixster, you won't be able to use the Apple TV to play it like you would on a PS3, XBox, Google TV, Samsung Smart TV or any of a number of open systems.Unless.That is, unless you have OSX Mountain Lion. If you do, you with one click, AirPlay everything on your computer on your television. Everything that's on your computer is on your television, including the sound. It's a great feature for making presentations or simply watching a movie.And it helps you subvert the brilliantly engineered iTunes Monopoly that comes installed with every product Apple sells.
